summary.seg: This manuscript, probably produced in the first half of the 16th century, contains a Miscellany of canon law and other texts in Greek. The largest component, accounting for the majority of the manuscript, is the compendium of canon law compiled from earlier collections by the 14th-century monk and theologian Matthaios Blastares. This collection is organised by topics arranged in alphabetical order, and became a standard reference work across the Orthodox Christian world. The other content includes a variety of briefer canon law texts, particularly relating to penance and marriage, and excerpts from collections of civil law. The manuscript also contains a wide range of other texts including including lists of ecclesiastical offices, short chronicles and chronological lists, miscellaneous religious texts, a brief Hebrew-Greek lexicon and other linguistic lists.

The manuscript was copied by many different hands, but is probably the product of a single project of production. The hand responsible for the largest proportion of the text appears at a number of points through the manuscript, and is identified by a colophon on f. 194r as the priest Theodosios Martinos.

There is evidence from water staining that the manuscript has been divided into at least two parts in the past, but the combination of hands and the watermarks in the paper suggest that this division does not result from the two parts having been produced separately but from later detachment. The manuscript was rebound in the early 17th century, using manuscript waste to form limp boards, within a leather cover.

The manuscript evidently spent time subsequently in southern Greece in the early modern period, as a note on f. 1r records its ownership by the hieromonachos (priest and monk) Nikephoros Pringelis, a native of Athens, while other notes mention the Metropolitan of Sparta and the ordination by the Metropolitan of Nauplion of a priest for Argos.

supportDesc.foliation: The manuscript is foliated with the numbers i-ii + 1-171, 173-174, 176, 180-186, 188-190, 193-197, 200-203, in pencil, in Arabic and Roman numerals, recto, upper right. Folio numbers 172, 175, 177-179, 187, 191-192, 198-199 have been assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practices at Cambridge University Library).
There is also intermittent pagination in pencil, in Arabic numerals, recto, upper right. From f. 124r these numbers are too small by two; from f. 151 they are correct.

binding.p: 17th-century full leather binding over limp pasteboards of manuscript waste, with leather sewing supports. There are remnants of two leather straps on the inside of the right board, and two holes where straps would have been laced on the left board.
binding.condition: The left inner joint is almost completely split. The boards have become partially delaminated. Both endbands have two breaks each. The tailband has lost much of the thread and has been rolled back onto the spine. The headband crown has become detached, and much of the decorative thread is worn.

provenance.p: Owned by the hieromonachos Nikephoros Pringelis Pringelis, Nikephoros of Athens, as indicated by his note on f. 1r.
Owned by the book collector George Dunn (1864-1912) Dunn, George, 1864-1912 , whose label appears on f. i verso.

history.acquisition: Purchased by Cambridge University Library in November 1917 in the auction of Dunn's collection (lot 3201).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

support.material: ff. i-ii Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Crescent ( 31 70 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Heawood 863. This example is dated to 1610.

supportDesc.condition: There is wear and tears to the edges of the endleaves, which have been repaired with Japanese paper,and a single worm-hole, which continues through ff. 1-6. The leaves are partially detached in the gutter, and there are tears to f. i where it has been attached to the left pasteboard and leather tabs from the cover wrapped around it. There is some water staining and areas of dirt.

additions.p: Some crude genealogical diagrams appear on f. i recto, possibly added by one Ioannes Ioannes , since part of the text reads ÎµÎ³Ï á½ á¼¸ÏÎ¬Î½Î½Î·Ï á¼ÏÏ Î¸ÎµÎ¹Î±Î½ ÎÎ±ÏÎ¯Î±Î½
On f. ii recto is a note listing five instances of the institution of divine law, from Adam to Moses.
On f. ii verso are two copies of the note on f. 9r.
A note of content in purple crayon has been added to f. i recto: Grammatica graeca.
There is a note on f. i verso regarding the manuscript's purchase at auction by Cambridge University Library: November 1917 Lot 3201.

physDesc.accMat: A slip of paper has been attached to f. i verso, printed with the words From the library of George Dunn of Woolley Hall near Maidenhead and the handwritten date 1917, by the same hand as the note on this folio.

history.origin: These endleaves were added when the manuscript was rebound in the early 17th century, as indicated by the watermark.

support.material: ff. 1-36 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Hat ( 49 48 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Likhachev 619. This example is dated to 1552.
ff. 37-53, 200-203 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Anchor ( 53 38 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 478, MoÅ¡in 651. These examples are dated to 1500-1502.
ff. 54-67, 83r-115v Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Hat ( 59 55 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Harlfinger Chapeau 41. This example is dated to 1506.
ff. 68-82, 116-123 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Hat ( 50 37 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 3407. This example is dated to 1527-1536.
ff. 124-131 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Anchor ( 50 35 ) in the centre of the folio, somewhat similar to Briquet 536-537. These examples are dated to 1560-1567.
ff. 132-171 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Hat ( 70 45 ) in the centre of the folio, similar to Briquet 3417. This example is dated to 1540-1541.

ff. 173-176 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Scales ( 60 30 ) in the centre of the folio, whose motif is similar to Harlfinger Balance 48, but with no discernible countermark. This example is dated to 1507.
ff. 180-197 Western paper, folded in folio. Watermark: Scales ( 65 37 ) in the centre of the folio, the main motif similar but not identical to Mazzoldi 309. This example is dated to 1520.

collation.p: The main body of the manuscript consists of 17 quires, of which one is a binion, one a quaternion, five are quinia, three were of 12 folios, one of 14, four of 16, one of 18 and one of 24 folios.

list.item: Quire 224-2 ff. 15-36 The last two folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 318-1 ff. 37-53 The tenth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 416-2 ff. 54-67 The fourth and fifth folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 516-1 ff. 68-82 The fifth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 616-1 ff. 83-97 The ninth folio has been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 710-3 ff. 98-105 The third, fourth and sixth folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 810-1 ff. 106-115 The last folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 910-2 ff. 116-123 The last two folios have been cancelled, without loss of text.
Quire 1410-7 ff. 173-176 The third, fifth and sixth folios have been cancelled, without loss of text; the first, eighth, ninth and tenth folios have been cancelled or lost, with some loss of text.
Quire 1510-3 ff. 180-186 The first and third folios have been cancelled, without loss of text; eighth folio has been lost, with loss of text.
Quire 1612-4 ff. 188-197 The fourth, fifth, eleventh and twelfth folios have been lost, with loss of text.

collation.signatures: There are signatures in Latin letters, in pencil, on the first folio of each quire, recto, lower right.

supportDesc.condition: Most of f. 200 has been torn away, and the lower outer corner of ff. 170-171 have been cut away, presumably following earlier damage. Large paper patches were previously attached to substitute for these losses, removed in 2019 and now housed separately. There is wear and tear to the edges of some folios, which has been been repaired with Japanese paper. Tears to ff. 83, 98-100 have been repaired with earlier paper patches. Some folios have become partially detached in the gutter. A single wormhole appears in the first few folios (ff. 1-6), continuing the hole in the front endleaves (ff. i-ii). There is widespread water staining, growing increasingly extensive proceeding rightwards through the manuscript as far as f. 176, and this has contributed to softening of the paper. Probably in part due to the weakening of the paper as a result of this, tears and holes appear through the lower part of ff. 155-176, which have been repaired with Japanese paper. There are areas of dirt.

handNote.p: The main text of ff. ff. 1r-123v, 180r-190v, line 2 and ff. 193r-197v was copied by Theodosios Martinos (Hand A) in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with considerable variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin. Flourishes and expansion of letters are often particularly dramatic and elaborate in the top line of text. There are deletions by expunctuation.

Syllabic abbreviations appear throughout the line, but superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines except in the top line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.

Distinctive letter-forms include majuscule beta with a very narrow upper loop and bulbous lower loop, and minuscule nu formed with loops to the left and lower right. There is a frequent ligature of tau-omicron with a small tau formed by a single curve joined to the top of omicron. The sigma telikon is present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.
Headings and original annotations to ff. ff. 1r-123v, 180r-190v, line 2 and ff. 193r-197v were copied by Hand B in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in red ink.
Breathings are round and there is accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to breathings and abbreviations.
The modern nu and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points.

ff. 124r-125v, line 13 and ff. 127r-131v were copied by Hand C in a mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in brown ink, with significant variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent or subscript. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron. There is a distinctive form of minuscule phi with a horizontally elongated upper loop.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings to these folios and to f. 125v, line 16-f. 126v are written in the same style in red ink.

The main text of f. 125v, line 16-f. 126v was copied by Hand D in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin. There are deletions by expunctuation and strikethrough.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is occasional decorative use of the double dot. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations.
The modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas, question mark and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.
ff. 132r-168r were copied by Hand E in a mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in black ink, with significant variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endingsappear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.

The modern eta, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron. There is frequent use of an omicron-upsilon ligature with an angular loop, often with greatly extended ascenders.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings and original annotations are written in the same style in red ink.
The notes to the diagram on f. 168r were copied by Hand F in an upright mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in orange ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations appear throughout the line. Breathings are round. There is decorative use of the double dot and abbreviation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, modern nu and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points and the lower and middle commas.
ff. 168v-171v were copied by Hand G in a mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in black ink, with moderate variation in letter size and frequent flourishing of tails into the margin.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.
The loop epsilon is present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron. The word ÎºÎ±Î¯ sometimes appears with the kappa included within the loop of the alpha.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Headings are written in the same style in red ink.
The main text of ff. 173r-176v was copied by Hand H in a mixed minuscule script with variable slant, in brown ink, with moderate variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and abbreviations. The double grave accent is in use. Horizontal strokes appear over proper nouns.

The modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron. The abbreviation of omicron-sigma is often joined to the letter below (e.g. f. 174r, line 1).
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and full stop.
Diagram labels on ff. 173r-176v were written by Hand I in a mixed minuscule, slanting to the right, in black ink.
Headings on ff. 173r-176v were written by Hand J in an upright mixed minuscule, in red ink.
f. 190v, lines 3-6 were copied by Hand K in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and there is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta and modern nu are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle point and full stop.
f. 190v, lines 7-13, 17-23 were copied by Hand L in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations appear throughout the line. Breathings are round. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle point, middle comma and full stop.
f. 190v, lines 13-16 were copied by Hand M in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
The only punctuation used is the middle point.
f. 190v, lines 23-34 were copied by Hand N in a mixed minuscule, slanting to the right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There isl decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters and nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present.
Punctuation used includes the middle comma and full stop.
f. 200r were copied by Hand O in a crude mixed minuscule script, slanting to the right, in black ink.
Breathings are round. Accents are sometimes joined to letters.
The modern eta, modern nu and loop epsilon are present.
ff. 200v-203v were copied by Hand P in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot and accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, abbreviations and nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, modern nu, sigma telikon and loop epsilon are present and there is inclusion of letters within omicron.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points and middle comma.

decoDesc.decoNote: The beginning of the text on f. 9r is preceded by a rectangular headpiece in red and black ink, topped with a cross with the words á¼¸Î·ÏÎ¿á¿¦Ï Î§ÏÎ¹ÏÏá½¸Ï Î½Î¹Îºá¾¶. On f. 138r the text is preceded by a plaited headpiece in red ink, in a much simpler style, topped with a similar cross design flanked by zoomorphic forms. A thin rectangular headpiece with a concertina design, in red and black ink, precedes the text on f. 180r.

Texts and sections begin with ornamented initials in red ink, with variable size and degees of elaboration. These include occasional zoomorphic forms (f. 6v). An initial on f. 2v has received additional adornment in green ink.
Subsections often begin with slightly expanded and sometimes slightly ornamented letters in red ink.
The end of sections is sometimes accompanied by line-fillers in red ink (e.g. ff. f. 31v, 96r).

additions.p: As part of the original production of the manuscript, various texts are accompanied by marginal section numbers, names of authors cited, other indications of content, and ÏÎ·(Î¼ÎµÎ¯ÏÏÎ±Î¹) marks highlighting notable passages, in red or brown ink. The text of Blastares (ff. 1r-137v, line 10) has been provided with running heads giving book and chapter number.

The Athenian hieromonachos Nikephoros Pringelis placed an ownership note on f. 1r, which is obscured by stains, perhaps due to the use of reagents: á¼Îº Ïá¿¶Î½ ÏÎ¿á¿¦ ....ÎµÎ¹... á¼±ÎµÏÎ¿Î¼Î¿Î½Î¬ÏÎ¿Ï ÎÎ¹ÎºÎ·ÏÏÏÎ¿Ï Î ÏÎ¹Î³Î³ÎµÎ»ÎµÏÏ ÏÎ¿á¿¦ ÎÎ¸Î·Î½Î±Î¯Î¿Ï .
A note on 55r refers to the Metropolitan of Sparta: Î Î±Î½Î¹ÎµÏÏÏÎ±ÏÎµ Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ¿ÏÎ¿Î»Î¯ÏÎ± Ïá¿Ï á¼Î³Î¹Î¿ÏÎ¬ÏÎ·Ï Î¼Î·ÏÏÎ¿ÏÏÎ»ÎµÏÏ ÎÎ±ÎºÎµÎ´Î±Î¹Î¼Î¿Î½Î¯Î±Ï á½ÏÎµÏÏÎ¹Î¼Îµ.
Additional chronological items have been added to the end of the text of Xanthopoulos on f. 164v by a later hand.
A note on f. 184v, dated 1625, refers to the priest Demetrios Demetrios, priest, ordained priest of Argos by Theophanes, Metropolitan of Nauplion Theophanes, Metropolitan of Nauplion.

There are other occasional marginal annotations and pen-trials by later hands, e.g. ff. 9r, 36v, 140r, 168v-169v, 197v. Some notes have been obscured by the possible use of reagents, in the same way as the ownership note of Nikephoros Pringelis: ff. 147v, 197v.

history.origin: The manuscript was copied in the first half of the 16th century, as indicated by the combination of watermarks and the style of script. The significant water damage to the folios leading up to f. 176 and the lack of similar damage to those from f. 180 onwards could suggest that ff. 180-203 are of a different origin from the earlier part of the manuscript. However, the commonality of hands and date of the papers suggests that this was all originally one manuscript, but that the later quires at some point became detached from the rest, which then suffered water damage, before it was rebound and the detached quires reattached.

msItem.title: On consanguinity and affinity
msItem.note: These fragments, formerly attached to f. 171 to replace its losses, have been written with text substituting the text lost from that folio through damage or covered by these patches. However, comparison between this text and that surviving in the covered areas of the folio shows that the two do not match, suggesting that this substitution was the product of conjecture rather than copying from a source text.

msItem.title: On consanguinity and affinity
msItem.note: This text of this fragment, formerly attached to f. 200 to replace its losses, does not correspond to the original content of the folio.

support.material: fragments 1-3 Western paper, folded in folio. Part of a watermark survives on fragment 1, but the main motif has been lost.

supportDesc.condition: There is slight water staining and areas of dirt, as well as residue from the glue used to attach the patches.

handNote.p: Fragments 1-3 were copied by Hand Q in a mixed minuscule script, slanting to right, in black ink, with modest variation in letter size.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear throughout the line. Breathings are round and mute iota is absent. There is accentuation of all nomina sacra. Accents are sometimes joined to letters, breathings and nomina sacra strokes.
The modern eta, modern nu and sigma telikon are present.
Punctuation used includes the lower, middle and upper points, lower comma and question mark.

history.origin: These patches were probably added to replace losses in the 17th or 18th century, as suggested by the style of script.
